passages.text: Consumer | Global Beverages
Brown- Forman BF/B| \(28.85 In\Line |\text{Target Price / Base Case:}\) 30.00 Company Update
Company StatisticsMarket Capitalization (M)$14,641Enterprise Value (M)$15,91852-Week Range$25.53 - $25.53Dividend/Share0.72Dividend Yield2.4%Fiscal Year EndApr
1 Year Price History

BF's results were ahead of expectations, with organic sales \(+1\%\) vs. Street \(- 3.8\%\) ; However, much of the upside was driven by a \(4\%\) benefit from inventory levels. Moreover, underlying U.S. total distilled spirits trends remained down LSD%, with BF delivering organic sales \(- 2\%\) ; However, this included a \(6\%\) benefit from inventory build related to the upcoming launch of Jack Daniel's Tennessee Blackberry and the distribution transition. Normalizing for the inventory build, U.S. organic sales trends sequentially weakened due to anticipated headwinds from the transition. We expect shipments and depletions to normalize by YE, which will drive lower shipments and higher depletions over the remainder of the year. More broadly, we remain concerned given weak industry data, driven by the following factors:

Structural Industry Issues: In August 2024, we wrote a report, New structural changes in U.S. spirits challenge Diageo, Brown- Forman, others, which pointed out, among other things, that more competition in the U.S. market from players such as Sazerac and Gallo could pressure BF. As shown on page 2, BF has been losing share in Whiskey and Tequila, with Whiskey losses primarily due to Sazerac's success. Following that report, we published Jack in a Box? A closer look at Jack Daniel's in September 2024, which dove into the challenges facing the JD family of brands
Structural Demand Issues: In the U.S., concerns on the impact from health & wellness, Gen Z drinking habits, GLP- 1s, cannabis / hemp use, and less socialization, incl. impact from online gambling
Consumer Pressure: Stretched wallets and prioritizing spend on experiences are impacting demand, especially for Gen Z. Our latest survey indicated that consumer pantries fell in July
Distributor Transition: U.S. RTM changes as BF shifts distribution in 14 markets
Please see more detail below:

Since March 2024, Brown- Forman lost share in Spirits in all months except for 1, lost share in Domestic Whiskey in all months except for 4, and lost share in Tequila every month; Overall Spirits market share trends flattered by relative outperformance of Domestic Whiskey and Tequila vs. other categories
Sazerac is the largest share gainer in Domestic Whiskey since March 2024; Suntory Global is another consistent share gainer, while Brown- Forman, Heaven Hill, and Diageo are consistent share donors

FY26 guidance reiterated: The company noted that "continue[s] to anticipate the operating environment for fiscal 2026 to be challenging with low visibility due to macroeconomic and geopolitical volatility as we face headwinds from consumer uncertainty, the potential impact from currently unknown tariffs, and lower non- branded sales of used barrels." Guidance incorporates anticipated disruption from U.S. RTM changes
Organic sales / operating income guidance of down LSD% vs. Street - 2.6% / - 3.0% Capex guidance of \(125 - 135M\) ETR expected to be \(21 - 23\%\)
Also of note, on August \(25^{\mathrm{th}}\) , the company announced that CFO Leanne Cunningham will retire on May 1st, 2026, after more than 30 years with the company
- BF expects FY26 depletion trends for the U.S. and Developed International to be similar to FY25, which were \(-2\%\) and \(-3\%\) , respectively; U.S. total distilled spirits trending down LSD%

- Expecting shipments/depletions to reverse in F2Q, leading to in-line F1H trends- We assume a \(\sim 50\) bps impact from the removal of American brands from Canadian shelves, which began in February 2024- Upbeat on opportunity for Jack Daniel's Blackberry, which it believes could be as large as other flavored innovations, such as Honey, which is \(4.3\%\) of volumes – we believe Blackberry could contribute \(\sim 1\%\) this year. The company also plans to launch more RTDs in the U.S., which are on-trend with the consumer's desire for convenience and flavor- Expect LSD% pricing globally, with some high inflation markets above LSD% and markets like the U.S. closer to flattish; Product mix headwinds from agency brand and RTD strength, especially in Japan and Mexico. As of F1Q, American Whiskey industry pricing flattish, with some pressure on Tequila – category rational overall
- We expect a \(\sim 1.5\%\) headwind from lower used barrel sales
- Used barrels contributed \(\sim \$ 100M\) of net sales to FY25 and management expects declines of over \(50\%\) in FY26 given the more difficult macro climate
- U.S. also likely to see headwinds over F1H26 from distributor changes – see 5/29/25 release
- Distribution changes are across 14 markets, including large markets of CA, NY, and TX
- Transition as of August 1st
- Company believes the change better positions them to sell evolved portfolio, including more RTDs and now expects to see more focus on its portfolio of brands overall
- Emerging Markets grew \(9\%\) over FY25, with continued outsized strength in FY26 likely. We believe the markets will continue with mid-teens% organic growth, similar to the \(15\%\) in F1Q

- We expect GM % to expand modestly as price/mix and removal of Finlandia/Sonoma TSAs more than offset input cost pressure (indirect tariff impacts on COGS more than offset agave decreases), unfavorable fixed cost absorption, product mix headwinds from faster growth of RTD portfolio and agency brands, and mix impact from lower used barrel sales, which are likely a

\(\sim\) \(60M\) hit to GP given the very minimal cost case on the sales of used barrels. Note, we believe BF is seeing smaller benefits from agave than peers given that a large amount of it is internally sourced vs. bought at spot, with additional limitations due to slower Tequila trends

- A&P was down \(\sim 6\%\) over FY25, and we expect a more modest \(\sim 2\%\) decline YoY in FY26, which implies \(\sim 30\) bps more A&P as a \(\%\) of sales and is near our expectation for sales. In FY25, the decrease was partially driven by the lapping of support behind the Jack Daniel's RTD launch- SG&A benefits will help offset higher A&P as a \(\%\) of sales, with the company benefitting from its restructuring / cooperage closures as well as lower compensation

Brown- Forman reported a better- than- feared F1Q26 (ended 7/31) and reiterated its guidance. BF reported organic net sales of \(+1\%\) vs. Street \(- 3.8\%\) ; However, this was aided by \(4\%\) from distributor inventory levels, with a \(6\%\) benefit in the U.S. and \(10\%\) in Emerging Markets. Sales upside was accompanied by GM \(\%\) of \(59.8\%\) vs. \(59.3\%\) Street, with 40 bps of YoY expansion driven by the positive effect of the divestitures, partially offset by higher costs, unfavorable price/mix, and the negative effect of foreign exchange. EPS of \(\) 0.36\(was below Street\) \ \(0.38\) ; However, underperformance driven by a \(\) 0.02\(headwind from restructuring charges and\) \ \(0.03\) from non- operating postretirement expense.

- U.S. \(-2\%\) vs. \(-4\%\) comp and \(-5\%\) in F4Q as net sales improved sequentially but remained weak. Net sales declines driven by the absence of the Sonoma-Cutrer prior-year TSA, lower volumes of Jack Daniel's Tennessee Whiskey and Herradura, and the end of Korbel relationship, partially offset by strong initial shipments for the upcoming launch of Jack Daniel's Tennessee Blackberry and in preparation for the August 1st, 2025, distributor transitions in the United States. Early in transition but pleased with initial progress. Notably, shipments drove a 6% tailwind to F1Q sales
- Management upbeat on opportunity from small bottles, which are an affordable luxury- Promo environment rational but consumers still seeking value
- Canada: Organic net sales declined \(\sim 60\%\) as U.S. brands remained off the shelf; However, non-U.S. brands continued to see growth

- Developed International \(-9\%\) vs. \(-6\%\) comp and \(-9\%\) in F4Q. Net sales declines due to soft consumer demand impacted by macro and geopolitical uncertainty. The decline was led by lower volumes of JDTW in Germany and the United Kingdom, along with the absence of American-made alcohol from retail shelves in most of the Canadian provinces, partially offset by the positive effect of foreign exchange and the benefit from the transition to owned distribution in Italy. Promo environment in Europe remains competitive. Inventories had a \(-1\%\) impact on F1Q sales

- Emerging Markets \(+25\%\) vs. \(-5\%\) comp and \(+12\%\) in F4Q. Results driven by higher volumes across the JD family of brands, which were led by Brazil and Turkey and partially benefited from an increase in distributor inventories as well as DD% growth of New Mix, partially offset by the negative effect of foreign exchange. Notably, inventories benefitted F1Q results by \(+10\%\) . This impact was primarily due to the UAE and should fall off to lower levels going forward, with the only impact remaining some rebuild in Uruguay and Paraguay

- Mexico: Economic environment challenging with consumers trading down, but organic sales grew \(+22\%\) and gaining share. Leading category in RTDs- Brazil: Organic net sales \(+30\%\) due to strength in JDTW in São Paulo and further geographic distribution; Premiumization remains an opportunity

- Travel Retail \(+7\%\) vs. \(-8\%\) comp and \(-14\%\) in F4Q driven by higher volumes of JDTW and Gin Mare, partially due to the timing of shipments, as well as the positive effect of foreign exchange

Maintain In Line. We are concerned by persistent weakness in Spirits demand across developed markets and market share losses in the U.S. Near- term results are likely to remain choppy with weak category demand weighing on valuation. Shares likely to remain range bound until investors see signs of improving Spirits category trends. Brown- Forman has tremendous brand assets, a demonstrated record of patient and effective innovation, and a long growth runway. The current P/E of \(\sim 18x\) compares with an average P/E of \(\sim 30.5x\) over the last ten years, which appropriately discounts incremental category risk.
Please see below for links to relevant reports, valuation, scanner / NABCA data, and more

New structural changes in U.S. spirits challenge Diageo, Brown- Forman, others  U.S. Spirits: Smaller bottle sizes outperforming. Path out for Spirits industry?  Latest Gallup poll concerning for alcohol industry: Younger consumers showing incremental H&W concerns  Deep Dives: Jack Daniel's / Woodford Reserve / Sazerac  DGE: FY25 Results / Guinness Investor Event  Pernod: FY25 Results  Industry Data: NABCA / TBA Census Inventories / DISCUS / Survey on U.S. home bars  "Make it a Double" - BF Analyst Day introduces long-term objectives  CEO and CFO meetings: Key takeaways from our HQ visit with BF management  Down the hatch: What happened to U.S. Spirits 2008- 2009

Target is based upon \(\sim 18x\) our C2026 EPS estimate

Downside risks include tariffs, continued supply chain challenges, commodity and logistics costs, erosion in pricing power for Jack Daniel's, consumer tastes shifting away from brown spirits, and RTD growth possibly impacting brown spirits. Upside risks include better than expected U.S. top line momentum, stronger than expected U.S. and global growth for Jack Daniel's #7 as well as from its RTD Jack & Coke launch, and greater than expected growth in emerging markets, including China and India.

Time of dissemination: August 28 2025 2:48 PM ET

Evercore ISI's recommendations are based on a stock's total forecasted return over the next 12 months. Total forecasted return is equal to the expected percentage price return plus gross dividend yield. We divide our stocks under coverage into three primary ratings categories, with the following return guidelines:
Outperform- the total forecasted return is expected to be greater than the expected total return of the analyst's coverage sector.
In Line- the total forecasted return is expected to be in line with the expected total return of the analyst's coverage sector.
Underperform- the total forecasted return is expected to be less than the expected total return of the analyst's coverage sector.

Coverage Suspended- the rating and target price have been removed pursuant to Evercore ISI policy when Evercore is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or strategic transaction involving this company and in certain other circumstances.

Rating Suspended- Evercore ISI has suspended the rating and target price for this stock because there is not sufficient fundamental basis for determining, or there are legal, regulatory or policy constraints around publishing, a rating or target price. The previous rating and target price, if any, are no longer in effect for this company and should not be relied upon.
Prior to October 10, 2015, the "Coverage Suspended" and "Rating Suspended" categories were included in the category "Suspended."

FINRA requires that members who use a ratings system with terms other than "Buy," "Hold/Neutral" and "Sell" to equate their own ratings to these categories. For this purpose, and in the Evercore ISI ratings distribution below, our Outperform, In Line, and Underperform ratings can be equated to Buy, Hold and Sell, respectively.
